description.text: test

Hell's Gate: Evil Leader of the Wastelands
Background:
Modioworld, a robotic utopia were Modionics (robotic civilians) live peacefully and coexist with each other, is in constant danger from the evil that always lurks on the outskirts of this perfect society.
Outside of the Modioworld lies the Wastelands, where Hell's Gate, the evil leader, is constantly gathering forces to take over and reign over Modiowoworld.
Hell's Gate is the archenemy of the Modioworld Guardians, Heaven's Gate, Terra's Gate, and Aqua's Gate.
Check out the guardian of the Heavens.
Heaven's Gate:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:479793
Check out the guardian of the Oceans.
Aqua's Gate:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:485099
For Makerbot Modio Challenge:
Why is it useful?
This design is useful as a source of endless fun. It provides the young at heart the possibility to have a physical representation of an imaginary world of robot creatures.
How is it novel?
This is a novel use of Modio pieces for the creation of robotic mythological figures that have been given an original back-story and personality within the futuristic realm of "Modioworld" where the possibilities are endless.

Created using Modio iPad app.
Print in groups 1 through 10 for your convenience.
COLORS
1: WHITE
2: WHITE
3:YELLOW
4:YELLOW
5:BLACK
6: BLACK
7: BLACK
8: RED
9: RED
10: RED
You may also print parts individually.

Multirotor with tennis ball drop, designed for ACV competition. Current maximum speed is 144 km/h.
See my post on DIYDrones for more info and parts list. http://diydrones.com/profiles/blogs/printed-high-speed-avc-copter-and-crash I suggest building with ABS using a 20% fill and 4 or more outer layers. To build these objects I used support material and raised the whole part off the bed so it was completely supported by the support material. This results in support material inside the arms that must be removed with a screw driver. Be careful not to spit the arms during removal of the support material.

Hace unos días un familiar me pidió una tuerca de Métrica 18 y paso de 2 mm, ya que se le había roto la bomba de achique del barco. Tras buscar tuercas en Solid Works y no encontrar la de Métrica 18 y paso 2 mm, decidí construirla desde cero a partir de las definiciones geométricas de la norma DIN 13. Adjunto el fichero DWG.
A la hora de construir las piezas he dejado una holgura de unas 100 micras entre las roscas para facilitar su acople.
Una vez impresa, he tenido que limar levemente la rosca del tornillo, ya que en los puntos en los que en cada capa comienza a imprimir el extrusor dejaba un pequeño resalte. Una vez limado levemente con una cuchilla funciona a la perfección.
A pesar de estar impreso con un infill del 30%, se ve bastante solida y resistente.
Impreso en PLA a 200º C y con una resolución de 200 micras.
aAquí un video del resultado:
http://youtu.be/Fa_MnYPb6zE
Ready to print

comments.text: hola con que programa has diseñado la rosca??Un saludo
comments.author: Josesese

comments.text:
Hola Josesese. Lo hice todo con Autocad. De memoria porque hace tiempo que lo hice, pero fue algo así:
Primero localicé las definiciones geométricas del Tornillo de la métrica específica. Norma DIN 13.
Con el comando HELIX, hacemos la hélice del tornillo/rosca, indicando centro, radio, paso, altura, número de vueltas....
Luego dibujas el perfil del "diente o muesca" de la rosca/tornillo, (sacas los parámetros de la carta DIN 13.
Después eso lo colocas en el extremo de la hélice, orientado perpendicular a la misma y extrusión por trayecto, normal a la hélice. Con eso ya tendrías el "diente" para restar al cilindro de la rosca.
El resto es coser y cantar.
No se si te ha sido de ayuda, pero recuerdo que no fue excesivamente complicado.
Por cierto, creo que el inventor o el Solid Works van mejor para este tipo de trabajos, pero no los domino. Intenté localizar ese tornillo en el parametrizador de SolidWorks, pero de esa métrica concreta no lo localicé.
En saludo

Well this is finally a lock box that works. It takes a couple prints to pull off but it works in the end. Skip the instructions and just use common sense if youre clever enough ;)
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kq4WPenqdDM

Print part one. Print part 2. Print part 3. Print part 4. Print top cover (or something like that). Take all of the parts off of the raft (needed) and smooth the everything from print one. Trim part 2's sides so that it fits in part 3 without too much friction. After this, insert the round piece with the smaller diameter top into print 2 so the top is flush with what was where the raft was (the top). once this is achieved, pull it out. Grab the "ring" from print 4 (not the rotation prevention disc). Drill holes that are slightly smaller than the diameter of the wire you are putting through it (See picture). Push the wires through and trim them, mark holes on the smaller diameter half of print 1's drill holes that are slightly larger than the wire diameter. Put that part back in the hole of print 2. make sure it rotates freely. Next, add the rotation prevention disc from print 4 on top of the disc inside of print 2 so the arms in print one can slide in and out of the holes in print 2 but not too far (see picture). After this make two marks on opposite sides of the holes in the rotation prevention disc. Once this is done remove everything again, and drill out the marks you made on the circular thingy from print 1 (same size as the wire). Drill the same sized holes in the ends of the rods in print 1. clean these rods up so they slide through the arches. The ends will probably need to be flattened a little bit to clear the tabs. Assemble everything back to print 2 and do a quick check to make sure the ring turns the circular thingy (underneath the rotation prevention disc) make sure the rods slide in and out of the holes in print 2. After this push the tabs into the big box (print 3) This will take some force. Glue them in and possibly trim up everything so it all fits and slides. Glue the rotation prevention disc in carefully as not to get any on the circular thing under it. Put the top on the box and see if the locking mechanism works and actually locks it. If it doesnt, the rods need to be flattened more. Put on the topper thing to keep everything from falling out and BAM youre done!

remixed_from.title: Tab And Slot Module V1.3 With Customizer

remixed_from.author: SimCity
remixed_from.title: Greg's X Carriage with Quick Change Clip System

description.text:
Well finally printed it and almost worked strait off the bat. The tabs are a little bit too long at the moment and have to shave about 0.5mm off of them, may be tollerance setting.  
Basically bolt-on tabs on the bottom of the extruder and grooves in the x carriage that the tabs slide into and lock in place, takes about 3 second to take off an extruder, just twist and lift.  
And no addition hardware  
Print it just right and it will hold as good as a stock carriage.  
Note: Pictured without nozzle in place to make it easier to photo.  
UPTDATE:5 months later and I am yet to see the extruder wobble loose (at no point does the extruder move in such a way as to create a twisting motion) doubt the little locks I put in are even needed. 1 broke off and still works as intended without it.
UPDATE 2: Almost 3 years on and finally a part failed. one of the tabs broke as I tried to force it in a bit too tight. I recommend adding a washer between bolt head and the plastic that is just big enough to go to the end but not extend over. This gives it some added strength and makes it quite rigid

Print out the STL, you may need to change the tollerance setting for your printer capabilities.  
print off as many additional tabs as you have need of for other extruders.  
Instead of bolting the extruder to the carraige like normal. You bolt the 2 tabs in the same place instead, ensuring they face outward and are as straight as you can make them (don't need to be exact, the act of putting it on for the first time will align them)  
Thats basically it, other than installing the carriage as normal.  
Line up tabs with the 2 slots in the top, push it in all the way and then twist it (currently set to go clockwise, can be changed as it depends on the belt location if this is best). Do the reverse to take it off.

Flexible coupling parts between the frame and the saddle Printed in Filaflex on a Prusa i3.
(more details available at: http://www.fabriqueurs.com/fabrications)

description.text:
A case to locate a small and light led light on my two up printer. I sourced the parts from a $1 walmart flashlight. It is super bright! and can be attached with a ziptie to anywhere on a 3d printer.
Some soldering required.

Dismantle flashlight, battery cap screws off, SO DOES TOP, but it's on tight! Keep silver reflector, and led array.
Remove spring, solder positive wire to where spring was soldered. Solder negative wire to a corner solder point.
Insert reflector, in proper direction from back.
Insert wires thru hole.
Insert led array into reflector.
Slide back cover in place.
Power with 5v. Can tie directly into e end-stop power on printrboard.
Zip tie on something and let there be light!

description.text: RepRap Samuel is designed to reuse the vitamins and some parts from the Prusa Mendel i2 or the Mendel. As such, an owner of either of the RepRaps should be able to print the new parts on their existing 3D printer to rebuild it into Samuel.

description.header: NOTE: Files here are placeholders only
description.text: Find the details of this on the RepRap website at http://reprap.org/wiki/RepRap_Samuel. Latest part STLs can be found at https://github.com/silpstream/reprap_samuel. Support forum is at http://forums.reprap.org/read.php?151,418085

15 Jan 2015:
Added Melzi electronics holder, z-axis m6 parts, z-axis m5 parts, dual lm8uu holder for extra support for bed, extended fan arm, and gt2 belt parts.

The following components were used in this project:
  • Unbreakable Bar Clamp by mikepcw - https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:156384
  • Prusa Leveling Vertex by Ahasuerus - https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5703
  • Bed levelling thumb wheel by Wired1 - https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:29782
  • 40mm Supportless, Directed Cooling Fan Duct for MendelMax & Prusa by AeroMonkeyDork - https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:63123

comments.text:
Thank you :) Yes I was talking about the space between the LM8UUs.
I am printing the x-end-motor now. It seems to require a quite well calibrated printer to print, but it is looking good so far :)
Slic3r reports a non-manifold error.
I do think it would be nice with a m5 thread rod version, like Prusa i3 is using now.
comments.author: silpstream

comments.text: I've actually modified mine to a M6 threaded rod as that was the smallest that I could find at my local hardware shop. I'm on holiday so can't take pictures, but give me a few days and I'll update the files. Don't worry about having to reprint the X ends, as I printed M8-M6 adapters. I'll upload both the adapters and the stepper to M6 couplers after christmas. Moving to the smaller M6 definitely improved the print, plus it allowed me to maximise z-height cause the old M8 rods I had were too short for the new design as they were from my i2.
comments.author: FrankIdeas

comments.text:
Thank you very much :)
The dimensions I measured for the m5 nut is 7.96mm flat to flat and 8.92mm corner to corner.
Would it be possible to create a gt2 version of sam_x-belt-clip.stl since many prusa i2 uses this belt as well.
Again thank you very much.
comments.author: silpstream

comments.text: I put up the m5 parts that you'll need, as well as added gt2 belt clips for both the bed and the x-carriage. You'll find the files on the GitHub repository. Let me know if there are problems with them, cause I wasn't able to test them.
comments.author: FrankIdeas

comments.text:
The adapters fits a litle tight into the x-ends. I think a better solution would be to modify the x-ends to fit 6mm and 5mm and then just print some new x-ends, due to the fact that adapters has to be printed very precise.
But I must admit that you work is very promising. Many good thoughts.
comments.author: silpstream

comments.text: I'd agree that we should eventually be reprinting the entire x-end directly for the M5/M6 sizes. This is more a stop gap measure right now, that is faster and uses less plastic. I actually intend to design new pieces that will narrow the gap between the threaded rod and smooth rod, for compatibility with the i3. This way we can then choose any of the i3 x-ends to use here.

Variation on my own twisted basket. Allows different numbers of spokes on the left and right twists. Also the spokes are slightly changed to use a hull of a couple cubes instead of tipped cylinders. Its seems the hull may be more efficient in this case actually.

According to some theories the ideal number of spokes in each direction should be consecutive numbers from the Fibonacci series (1 ,1, 2, 3, 5, 8, 13, 21, 34, ... ) so use  13 and 21 or 8 and 13 perhaps. This theory maybe originated with the spiral arrangement of certain plants leaves and seeds, such as the sunflower seeds.

title: Wall Mounted Holder for iPad With Cover

description.text: If your wife wants to mount her ipad on the wall by the treadmill to listen to Pandora, consider this 10-piece snap-together bracket/holder for an iPad with cover. It is meant to be wall mounted with two screws. The file here is not monogrammed like the one in the picture, in case your initials are not KLH. This is my first "thing" that I created from Sketchup to PrintrBot.

Print one each of the following: FrontMiddle BackMiddle LeftBack_L RightBack_L Print Two of: Front_L Print four of: Stringer Printing a brim seemed to reduce curling at the corners.
Snap pieces together. The pieces snap pretty firmly together, but I recommend super-gluing the joints. The three back pieces have stand-off to hold the piece off the wall 1/8 inch the allow clearance for the snaps.

author: mariotje

description.text:
This is by far the strongest phone case that I have ever had. I have dropped my phone off the first story of my house in this case and it SURVIVED without a scratch on it. The ninjaflex outside absorbes most of the shick, while the PLA inside distributes it evenly. The two frame parts are in PLA but can be printed in ABS and the rubber outside is printed in ninjaflex, a highly flexible filament. All of these files don't need rafts or supports. You can add them if you feel like it though.   
PS: Thanks to all of the people on thingiverse that designed iPhone cases for me to base my design off of.  
Version 1.2 massive update I improved the quit button so it presses better i also modified the power button to press easer and I added a screen liner that you can glue to the frame top part for style and strength. Please not that: THE PICTURE AT THE TOP IS NOT UP TO DATE

I printed the two frame pieces in PLA on a makerbot replicator 2. I heat my PLA at 230 degrees Celsius but i think it varies for different printers.  For the ninjaflex rubber part I printed it also on the replicator 2 but heated the extruder to 220 degrees Celsius and set the extrusion rate to 30mms when extruding and 50mms while traveling. I also did not use supports or a raft for any of these parts. All of these parts can be slices in maker ware and can be printed on a replicator 2.

Derived loosely from the code for thing:21830 (Parametric Chair and Table) but not really a derivative.

title: grip adaptor for Well MB-06 Spring Sniper Rifle (Softair) to mount standard M4 grips (left)

description.text:
Hi folks,
I'd like to share a thingi I designed for my own purpose. It's an adaptor to mount a standard M4 grip I bought (Panther Sniper Style) to my ASG Urban Sniper Rifle (also known as Well MB-06 and ASR Echo 1).
It consists of two halfes (left and right one) and uses 4 pins (mandatory; diameter 2 mm, length 4 ... 6 mm) and 2 new screws with nut and washer, M5 (I used M5 x 30 hexagon head). Maybe you need to do some minor adjustments, depends on the grip, you're planning to use. Feel free to use, develop the thingi and comment or like. ;)
Have fun!
PS: I mounted it succesfully but have not yet field- and long term-tested it.

I used a student version of SolidWorks 2013 to create it. Great software. I just measured the parts and adapted the original part, to which the standard grip was mounted.
Just print/order the two (!!) halfes, put the nuts in it and you should be ready to go.

description.text: Monkey Fling Mesa (Hurricane Mesa) - Location of a rocket sled test track just Northwest of Virgin Utah...constructed with SRTM2STL using SRTM data from the Space Shuttle. The source code for creating these files is available up on github under the GNU license. Go to github and search for SRTM2STL. The lower left-hand coordinates are Latitude 37 degrees 11 minutes Longitude 113 degrees 15 minutes and the upper right-hand coordinate is Latitude 37 degrees 19 minutes Longitude 113 degrees 6 minutes. The map is about 246.3 sq. km (14.8 X 16.6 km).

You may want to print this to be relatively small. I get warping using PLA and it gets bad when I try to print Raised Relief Maps that are big. I have had 'some' success with big maps. If you have a way to control warping you may also have better luck with big maps.

description.text: This is a simple extension of thing:21830 (Parametric Chair and Table) to add a desktop to the chair to turn it into a school desk.

I printed this desk very small, at the 0.35 scale that has been put into the desk.scad file.  The desks were used as a substitute for houses in a school-based home-made version of the board game Monopoly.  In this OpenSCAD file, I rewrote much of the code for thing:21830 to replace the polyhedra with linear extruded simple rectangles.  To avoid requiring support material, I reoriented the chair sideways and wrote in my own support structures, which are two plates that support the top chair legs.  These supports should be removed after printing.  A brim of at least 1mm is recommended when creating the gcode, as otherwise the desk part has a very small connection to the base and will tend to pull off the base.

This bracket holds one 36mm Omniwheel by cbiffle (thing #705, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:705). It is printable in one build on a 3D Printer and uses the same (3mm) metal rod that the Omniwheel needs. Use this bracket to mount the Omniwheel to any flat surface. You can choose between two versions: Bracket-Solid has a solid base for drilling and mounting with bolts, or velcro, etc. Bracket-Cutout is the same except the base is "cut out" such that it is gluable and uses less plastic. See the pictures for clarification.

• Choose and download one of the bracket files. Open it in ReplicatorG and generate the Gcode using your favorite profile.

  • Print your bracket!

  • Mark your metal rod to the inside width of the bracket. Cut the rod so it will just fit inside the bracket walls. This rod will be the axle for the Omniwheel. Test fit the axle in the bracket by gently bending the walls outward and placing the axle in the cradles. The walls should squeeze back together so that the sides are square and the axle is secure. Remove the axle once you know it fits.

  • Trim any burrs from the inside of the axle holders (mount points), and trim the bushings off the ends of the Omniwheel so it will fit in the bracket between the mount points.

  • Slide the axle into the wheel, and snap the whole thing into the bracket. You can now mount your wheel to anything!

Concept leveraged from Emmett's spool holder, but this breaks up the single piece into 3 separate pieces. The problem with the single piece was that it was so long that warping was an issue, leading to many wasted print passes. Individual pieces allows each to be printed separately, then assembled together. The Guide piece, which is the longest piece which tends to warp, was created with a lot of open space beneath, but still strong enough to do its job. I've uploaded a second (improved?) version of this guide so choose which you would like.

Let's call the 3 parts the Base (the part that goes over both of the Z-rods), the Guide (the part that sticks out to guide the filament to the extruder), and the Shaft (over which the Spool is placed). The holes of the base may be slightly large compared to the Z-rods. If they are, wrap some painter's tape around the tip of the z-rod to tighten up to a snug fit - so that the base does not wobble on top of the z-rods. The Guide may be a tight fit into the slot on the Base - if it is, you can sand the guide down a bit. I had to use a mallet to tap the guide in place. There are now 2 versions of the guide - the 2nd version (improved?) offers more room for the filament to slide on and is more tolerant of different size spools. For the Shaft, do measure your diameters of your Spool reels to make sure that the smallest one can fit it.   
Let me know if you have suggestions for improvements!

description.text: A simple glowing lantern made from a bracket holding a "Breadboard friendly Neopixel" (colour-changing LED http://www.adafruit.com/products/1312) inside a milk bottle, which is a common size in the UK (38 mm neck). There are holes to suspend it - I intend to use these in a early-years children's play space. The grip assumes standard header has been soldered in place, making it an easy, modular system. Both the translucent and white bottles work well - I can't decide which I prefer.

This is a one-piece print, but the lantern needs the following:
  • 500ml Milk plastic bottles (38mm opening)
  • Neopixels with headers http://www.adafruit.com/products/1312
  • Cabling to drive and connect each unit to the next (standard alarm system 6-core wire works well and is cheap)
  • Strong to hand them (don't use the power cabling)
  • Arduino or equivalent to drive them (library free at Adafruit)

This is a simple bracket to be used in conjunction with balsa wood for students to make bridges using various truss options. Students first model expected forces on the bridge then build one and load it until it fails. We are also evaluating allowing the students to design and print their own brackets for a bridge of their design but we need to work out the workflow issues. The hope is that this provides not only a relevant and interesting use of 3D design and printing but also a more homogeneous connection point than glue thus allowing for a more accurate analysis of forces. This particular bracket is designed to work with the Balsa Wood strips from Pitsco http://www.pitsco.com/Balsa_Wood_Density_Strips?SKU=57470&

title: Double Whammy Prusa

description.text: The Double Whammy prints parts twice as fast because there are two extruders working simultaneously! The machine is intended for production, producing two copies of the same print at once. Built using my Push-me-pull-you extruder drive (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:46800) and a pair of Acarius10's Minimalistic J Head X Carriage (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:45883) fitted with a pair of 0.35mm J-head hotends (https://www.hotends.com/index.php?route=product/product&product_id=88). I think the hobbed bolt came from lulzbot (http://www.lulzbot.com/?q=products/hobbed-bolt-stainless-steel); the hob is 29mm from the cap (stl included). There is still some tweaking to be done (does it ever stop with these things?) but it seems to be working well.

03.09.13 - have had a lot of trouble with the FEP tubing blowing out of the drive-end nuts. Trying out some PTFE tubing now. Will update after a few hours of printing. With the exception of the sheath failure and sore thumbs from loading filament into the push-me-pull-you, it has been working excellently. The extruder is quiet as can be...
02.14.13 - uploaded micrograph of a pulley I printed on the DWP last night - pretty sweet if I say so myself! What has proven to be very nice is the ability to slow print speed down to improve print quality while still making parts at a much higher rate than before. I had some trouble with stripping PLA and plugging up the hobs with the idlers having only 1mm at-rest spring stretch and replaced them with idlers having 4mm stretch - seems much better.
Follow the instructions for the various bits.
The Bowden cable sheath is 2mm x 4mm FEP tubing.
Space the x-carriages at about 100mm on the x-axis.
Slice the parts with the x-axis size set at 100mm so that the print is properly centered in each print area.
I tried media from two different suppliers at the same time and was unable to complete the print. Even different colors seem to behave differently. Suggest that to minimize catastrophes, use the exact same material in both sides of the extruder.
Drink something yummy while your printer produces at twice the rate it ever did before.

Designed to cover an exposed HDD that I removed from my laptop to use as an external drive. Should be pretty standard across different HDDs, but mine in particular is a Hitachi 5k750-640. The cover allows cable access to the HDD, but if you have some sort of stand or non-conventional cable that connects to the hard drive then you may want to modify the model to make it fit. The cover is in two pieces - there are holes on the side of each piece which are for screws to fit into and hold each part onto the HDD. The "assembled" stl file is for viewing how this is supposed to work, whereas the "left" and "right" stl files are the ones you want to print.
I HAVE NOT PRINTED THIS ITEM YET. When I do, I will update the info on this page and make any appropriate adjustments.
Dimensions were measured with calipers and fitted to my particular HDD with holes for screws.

My interpretation of the legendary plane of the Red Baron. Fully equiped with OberÃ¼rsel engine, spandau machineguns and ofcourse tri decks of wings and appropriate maltese cross'
Hopefully it will bring joy and and lots of airplane noise to your desktop :)
A worthy enemy of the Fokker is in the making, either a Sobwith camel or a RAF SE. 5a
The model isnt made to an exact scale of the original, but it resembles the original as much as possible.

Rotate the various parts to fit your printer, all parts are designed without need for support and to minimize warp. My parts were printed with Faberdashery filament on an Ultimaker. Parts were sliced with a combo of Cura and Netfabb. Beware of the 3 wing parts, make sure they lay flat on the printbed, and they are printed with only 20% infill and reduced top and downskins to prevent warping. Print 4 of 10-29-10016, these are the same parts need for wing support.
Part 10-29-10014 must be made both in the version uploaded and in a mirrored version. All parts are glued together, once printed the positions should be self explanatory, else feel free to ask!

A autolevel for K8200 using a hall endstop.
.
Update on 2014-10-9 : Adding photos
.
Update on 2014-10-19 :
  • Support1b-V1.04-2 -> Support1b-V1.05 : bigger hole for the cable connector
  • Tests Ok With Marlin
    .
    Update on 2014-11-25 :
  • Adding electrical schema
    .
    Update on 2014-11-28 :
  • Publication of a more compact version, that can be mounted on the right side of the hothead :
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:568621

This autolevel usethis type of hall endstop :
http://www.reprapdiscount.com/electronics/18-set-hall-endstops3-pieces.html#
.
This montage requires 2 magnets, the first for the detection and the second for the park (this detectors are sold with two each).
.
For the screws you will need :
  • 5 x M3x10 (or 3xM3x10 and 2xM3x8)
  • 6 x M4x10
  • 3 xM5x20
  • 1 a threaded rod (M4x60)
    And some nuts :
  • 2 x M4
  • 3 x M5 (square nuts)
    .
    It can be a good idea to also take this wiring kit :
    http://www.reprapdiscount.com/electronics/49-ramps-basic-wiring-kit.html#
    .
    For Marlin I was inspired from this :
    https://github.com/magu/Marlin
    .
    Il was directly operational on a k8200 Stock (without modification)
    .
    And for the start GCode in Cura :
    G21
    G28 X0 Y0
    G29
    G90 ; use absolute coordinates
    G92 E0
    M109 S205 ; wait for temperature to be reached
    G1 E10 F400 ; prime the nozzle
    @pause

comments.text:
Nice Design!!
Tipp: to get 5 or 12 V to all the endstop connectors you can bridge a solder joint. You can nicely see it in the last picture you attached. Just above the red cable on your picture you can either bridge 12v or 5v to the middle solder point. After that you will have the selected voltage at your middle pin of each endstop connector. As the original endstops have no cable connected to the middle pin this works even in mixed scenarios where you have classical endstops and others.

Defender of the weak

This program allows you to make automatically generated puzzles. Each time you run the program you get a new puzzle. The program (though not customizer version) also allows you to turn any stl into a puzzle.
Customizer allows you to choose piece sizes, number of rows and columns, piece thickness and piece spacing. The OpenSCAD program allows you to control almost every aspect of the piece.

The program is pretty well documented so hopefully most of the questions are answered there.
You may need to experiment to see what values work best on your printer, such as the one that controls the spacing between the pieces. Too small and they fuse together.
I have been printing these on a raft so the first layer isn't smashed down and fusing the pieces.
Huge thanks to ckirby whose Bezier Library (thing:86713) made this possible.

description.text: This box is around 140X70X50 MM and is designed to print without support. The lid also latches into place.

TIPS
Watch out for warping! Use a brim if needed on the lid and box. The latch on the front can help a warped lid close more flush with box but won't help all that much.
The 2 hinge pins should snap gently into place. They are a fairly small piece so I recommend printing them with another item, otherwise they won't get enough cooling time between layers and you end up with a bad quality part.

This is a 16 inch rigid heddle loom with an 8 dent reed. You can make it as narrow as 8 inch or even wider by removing or adding middle reed pieces . Make the loom as long or short as you want based on your size and your work space. You will need 7/8", 7/16", and 1/2" dowel rods also #6 x 1/2" wood screws in addition to the printed parts.
I originally made this to sell, but shipping them proved to be more of a headache than I cared to deal with right now.Please don't be mean and try to sell this unless you want to send me a cut of your earnings for designing it. If you make this and enjoy it please consider dropping a buck or two my way - https://www.paypal.com/cgi-bin/webscr?cmd=_s-xclick&hosted_button_id=9ZKG4R88F6HK8

I'm not great at writing up instructions but I will include rendered sample pictures to help with the assembly. Feel free to contact me with any questions.
If you need help learning how to warp a rigid heddle loom check out this great video. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fa1WrHOTjxY
To simplify the weaving and warping process I changed the standard rigid heddle loom design. Tie your warp strings to one of the dowel rods instead of the warping stick like shown in the video. There will be no need to add strips of cardboard while rolling up your project because the knots will be hidden between the two dowel rods.
Because of my design changes I added a tension bar that keeps your work at a constant height instead of moving up and down as you roll up your project.

description.text: This creation marks which page you are in in books, and it has my name on it.

Everyone loves HotWheels cars, so why not [YourNameHere]Wheels for the cars that you design? I'm Les so my cars are LesWheels. HotWheels cars are 1/64 scale, or typically about two to three inches in length. I am open sourcing these designs so those with printers and know-how can print their own without paying a fee. Revision notes of this first car (named bLesSings) follow.
bLesSings8: I have not yet printed this model. This is my latest model after about three days of playing around with CAD and printing revisions as I go. I am learning techniques for making the models assemble-able as well as paint-able and print-able. One novelty I've come up with is the sprue sheet. Much like a sprue tree on a conventional injection molded model, the sprue sheet holds all the parts together and gives you a handle for painting them. The difference is that the sprue sheet exists as a bed-height one or two layer thick sheet covering the full sprue area. When the paint dries, you just trim the sheet with an x-acto knife to separate the parts.
bLesSings6: I have printed this model and it turned out just fine. This larger 1:36 scale model is just the body, fenders, and seat area with footholes that were later removed.

description.text: Every single xacto knife I have ever bought, a week later the cap is missing. Well not anymore. All I gotta do now is hit print. :)

I created this fully 3d printed airplane just to make something cool. With a 36 inch wingspan, 4 servos, and a 210w motor this is a fully functional flying airplane.
Parts:
4 - 25mm x 3mm or 1 inch #4-40 machine screws + respective bolts
4 - 40mm x 6mm or 1.5 inch x 1/4 inch bolts
8 - 6mm or 1/4 inch washers
4 - 10mm x 4mm or 1/2 inch x #6 machine screws + respective bolts
4 - 1/8 inch x 3/8 inch x 2 foot basswood or (untested) 1/8 inch x 1/4 inch x 2 foot basswood
piano wire or paperclips
rubber bands
glue (abs + acetone recommended for an abs print)
sandpaper
RC parts:
I used:
1 - TURNIGY Plush 30amp Speed Controller
1 - D2830-11 1000kv Brushless Motor
1 - ZIPPY Compact 2200mAh 3S 25C Lipo Pack
4 - Turnigy TG9e 9g / 1.5kg / 0.10sec Eco Micro Servo
As well as a battery charger and 4 channel transmitter/reciever
.
As a poor college student, if you are viewing this and work for a cool company i would love to hear from you about any possible employment. :)

Print settings:
I recommend printing at least the wings in ABS due to being able to glue and fill print imperfections with abs/acetone mix.
I used rafts on everything.
Wing sections should be printed vertically, as should most things in in this model because they are designed to not need supports.
Turn the body back and body tail to print vertically.
move the cover down on the Z axis until the top is within the print area.
2 shell 20% infill with supports:
  • body front
  • wing servo
    2 shell 20% infill no supports
  • everything else except tail pieces
    3 shell 5% infill no supports
  • tail flaps
    2 shell 5% infill no supports
  • tail and tail upper
    Assembly:
    Basswood:
    The basswood will not fit into the slots in the wings without trimming about 1/16 off the top of the 3/8 tall side. Using 1/8 x 1/4 basswood might work but i haven't tried it.
    Trim the end off the basswood so the entire piece is contained within the wing.
    Body:
    bolt the back of the body to the front with the #6 or 4mm bolts. Glue the body tail latice into the slot on the back of the body.
    Body servos:
    The ideal way to insert the servos is from the inside, the rear one first, you should be able to maneuver each servo into their respective bracket without much trouble. If not then some material from the triangular part of the hole will need to be cut out to allow for insertion from the outside. Either way the servos are held in place with a small plastic tab with a servo mounting screw threw it. the plastic from hard packaging cut into a 10x20mm rectangle works perfectly.
    Tail:
    The cylindrical parts of the tail flaps will need to be sanded down to rotate easily within their holes. The rectangular spires from the tail_upper are to be inserted into their holes in the base of the tail_upper piece. The tab on the elevator should be on the top left. Attach the elevator to the tail by angling the tail and sliding the elevator into each hole one at a time. Place the elevator assembly into the lattice of the body. Place the rudder into the small round hole with the tab on the right side. Slide the upper tail into the diamond holes and on the top cylindrical rudder tab. The tail assembly is secured via two rubber bands attached in a cross fashion, or more permanently by glue.
    Motor:
    Motor and mount first, followed by each cowl section, push motor wires through the hole on body, bolt everything together.
    Wing Aileron:
    There may be gaps in the print on the wing sections, use abs glue to fill any imperfections. One very important area to glue is the channel where the aileron attaches. It is likely that the channel has a gap running along the entire length of it. Pour a couple drops of glue and let them run from one end to the other to connect both halves of the section. sand the rounded aileron tab so that after the glue FULLY dries it can turn with little resistance but not too much to have it fall out. The aileron tab should be facing down and closer to the body.
    Wing servos:
    The servos should just snap in, the small bottom piece will probably break upon insertion, not a big deal, either glue it back together or leave alone. Attach the servo arm before assembling into the wing.
    Wings:
    slide two prepared basswood sticks into each wing tip. Next slide the aileron/middle wing section. Followed by the servo and base wing sections. Using two rubber bands placed outside the wing along each basswood stick to clamp it together, glue all of the wing sections together.
    Landing gear:
    Snap wheels onto the clips, sanding where necessary to have the wheels spin freely. The landing gear is optional.
    Wing to body assembly:
    Tapping each wing is suggested. But tapping with a bolt is possible, just be careful. Each bolt has two washers against it's head. Route the servo cable through the hole in the landing gear and body. Bolt each wing on securely. Using too much force can and will crack the plastic. The wing servos need a splitter so buy one or splice one servo into the other.
    Final assembly:
    Add all electronics, using the transmitter, find the neutral spot for all of the servos and make linkages out of piano wire or paperclips to all of the flight control surfaces. The cover is attached via two rubber bands and a paperclip.
    • Have Fun :)

comments.text: If you have to ask any of those questions, you shouldnt be printing OR trying to fly RC planes. Youre going to injure someone, possibly yourself, and crash the plane. That is, if you can even print it. This is a very advanced project bud. Its not something you just throw on the plate. You need high resolution nozzles or mid range with a single shell, which any maker will tell you, is a very frustrating process. Once you print it, you have to learn servos, radios, receivers, control surfaces, very precise assembly, etc, etc.... THEN you have to learn to fly it, and if this is your first RC plane, you are going to be very upset when it crashes. And since its printed, it takes longer and is harder to repair, most of the time it would require a complete reprint, and you will inevitably have fractures between layers on other parts, from shock, which is dangerous to fly with. Its not like balsa and Mono-kote planes. Which is what you need to learn on first. There are special trainer planes for beginners that can take a beating and are easy to fly. This thing is not going to be easy to fly. Please use your head dude. And as far as printing, you have a good year or 2 before youre ready for something like this, given you just started, and no I'm not kidding or trying to be an asshole, you really need to cram hard for this one.

comments.author: wersy

comments.text: Jesus dude. Mine is about 410 grams total with all the equipment. The motor and battery added a couple ounces, and the battery isnt very big because of weight issues. That was with 2 shells and matching top and bottom height (respective to double shell width) and 10% 3d honeycomb infill. Yours doesnt fly does it? Thats because its a fatty lol ;) . It took mine 4.5 days. Total material was somewhere close to 10 grams. That does not include any fittings or cyanoacrylate. No it hasen't flown yet either. I think you will find your landing gear design a little anemic and it doesnt spin well. I recommend just using hobby store gear. they make rubber foam wheels that are light weight and perfect for this. Theres also light weight aircraft aluminum or carbon rod arms that you can get for them, but theyre a little more expensive than steel. Ill post some pics and maybe a video if i can keep it in the air lol.

comments.author: DennyNC

comments.text: It's a fast flying, maneuverable airplane. However this being the first and only airplane i have ever flown doesn't really make me a good judge.
comments.author: DennyNC

comments.text: Something tells me you crashed it >.<  lol dont worry thats why trainers exist, we all had to learn the hard way. As for speed, no this is not a fast airplane nor can it handle high gforces, its more of a mid to low range plane. It flys at about 30mph MAYBE 45mph for this type of design in general. It will depend heavily on your skill in printing (material usage / weight / scale. But my Shrike Speed goes up to about 85-90, and the jets go way above that, Some up to 200. The record is 440mph. It was a single engine ducted jet engine on a custom mono-wing fuselage. So no this thing isnt very fast at all, its barely faster than my .40 Piper Cub, and thats a sleeper. Not as slow as some gliders though.
comments.author: Kiril_Lange

comments.text: Nice. It looks fast. I'd probably have it back into kit form after the first flight. I better stick to quads.

comments.text: You are correct, it does fly fast and definitely isn't a beginner plane. I hand launched it easily but the handling was a bit sensitive. I'm sure an experienced pilot would have no troubles flying it.

title: Adafruit Ohm Sweet Ohm Cross-Stitch Kit

description.text: A cross-stitch kit that's also a resistor chart! Not only is this kit fun to make (and good for beginner stitchers), when it's all done it functions as a handy resistor reference chart. This Adafruit original kit comes complete with everything you need to get started: https://www.adafruit.com/products/855 14-count aida cloth - 15"x18" 6" embroidery hoop (Susan Bates "super grip lip" style) Two size 24 tapestry needles All the floss you'll need to stitch this design - 16 skeins in total Full color printed pattern and instructions Finished design fits perfectly in a frame measuring 8"x10". This fun project will give you about 40 hours of relaxing crafting enjoyment.

You can download the PDF instructions for this kit, which includes the Ohm Sweet Ohm pattern, required floss quantities, and specific instructions and tips. We have a complete guide to cross-stitching over on our Cross-stitch Tutorial page: http://learn.adafruit.com/cross-stitch If you wish to modify the original pattern, design files have also been included -- the charted pattern consists of a low-res Photoshop file which is then overlayed with a grid in Illustrator. Adafruit invests time and resources providing this open source design, please support Adafruit and open-source hardware by purchasing products from Adafruit! Creative Commons Attribution, Share-Alike

A 3D-printable token to release shopping carts. The key has a hole so that it can be carried on a keyring and always handy.
We provide two versions as STL files. One in the shape of a Swedish 10 kronor coin, and a blank so that it can be used for any size of coins.
Just 3D-model a simple flat cylinder in the size of your coin and (Boolean) join it with the blank.

comments.text: Thanks for sharing.  Even with ABS, I had to print out several of them until I got my settings just right.  Most of them would delaminate because the phone snapped in too tight.  Feel free to play with the scale a tad if it fits too tight.

comments.text: Tried a 1mm thickness and that was way too much as the phone didn't fit.  Went back to .6mm and increased to 25% fill (still PLA) and that seems to be working a few days later.  Printed one out as a gift for a friend who also just got an S5.

description.text:
If you enjoy fixing things in your car by yourself, keep on reading.
1 get a car with bayonet clip wiper blade;
2 check out if your windshield wiper is bayonet type;
3 if your wiper clip isn't bayonet type, go to step 1;
4 print the stl file;
4 Raise the metal windshield wiper arm away from your car’s windshield until it stays in place. Make sure that you are careful at this point, because this metal arm is spring loaded and may come crashing down against the glass, which could cause a crack.
5 with stl printed, and with the windshield arm perpendicular to the ground, take the new printed clip and insert it into the hook of the arm, raising it away from your hood until the plastic hook piece snaps into place with your wiper arm. Now you have changed your wiper blade clip! Slowly allow the arm and new wiper blade to settle against the windshield.

title: Adjustable endstop trigger for graber i3 / prusa i3

description.text:
An endstop trigger for the Z axis of a graber i3 or prusa i3 reprap printer. Clamps on the left side of the Z axis. As you can see from the photo, it uses M3 screw + spring + 2 separators + one M3 nut.  
It works great with Thing 83680 amongst others.

• Fit M3 nut on the depression
  • screw in the M3 screw with the separators and spring.
  • Adjust as necessary to trigger the endstop holder below it (which is a separate part, not from this entry).
